question: A function f from the set of natural numbers to integers defined by
eqn_key_0
equation:
\begin{align*}
\text{We have } f : \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{I} \\
\text{Let } x \text{ and } y \text{ be two even natural numbers, and } f(x) = f(y) \Rightarrow \frac{-x}{2} = \frac{-y}{2} \Rightarrow x = y \\
\therefore f(n) \text{ is one-one for even natural numbers.} \\
\text{Let } x \text{ and } y \text{ be two odd natural numbers and } f(x) = f(y) \Rightarrow \frac{x-1}{2} = \frac{y-1}{2} \Rightarrow x = y \\
\therefore f(n) \text{ is one-one for odd natural numbers.} \\
\text{Hence } f \text{ is one-one.} \\
\text{Let } y = \frac{n-1}{2} \Rightarrow 2y + 1 = n \\
\text{This shows that } n \text{ is always an odd number for } y \in \mathbb{I} \quad \ldots (i) \\
\text{and } y = \frac{-n}{2} \Rightarrow -2y = n \\
\text{This shows that } n \text{ is always an even number for } y \in \mathbb{I} \quad \ldots (ii) \\
\text{From } (i) \text{ and } (ii) \\
\text{Range of } f = \mathbb{I} = \text{codomain} \\
\therefore f \text{ is onto.} \\
\text{Hence } f \text{ is one-one and onto both.}
\end{align*}
ques.subject: Maths
ques.topic: Topic should be like this Sets, Relations, And Functions

question:
If f : R → S, defined by f (x) = sin x − √3 cos x + 1, is onto, then the
interval of S is
equation:
\begin{align*}
\text{Given that } f(x) \text{ is onto} \\
\therefore \text{range of } f(x) = \text{codomain} = S \\
\text{Now, } f(x) &= \sin x - \sqrt{3} \cos x + 1 \\
&= 2 \sin \left(x - \frac{\pi}{3}\right) + 1 \\
\text{we know that } -1 &\le \sin \left(x - \frac{\pi}{3}\right) \le 1 \\
-1 &\le 2 \sin \left(x - \frac{\pi}{3}\right) + 1 \le 3 \\
\therefore f(x) &\in [-1, 3] = S
\end{align*}
ques.subject: Maths

question:
Let R = {(1,3),(4, 2), (2, 4),(2,3),(3,1)} be a relation on the set A = {1,
2,3, 4}.. The relation R is
solution:
∵(1, 1) ∉ R ⇒ R is not reflexive
∵(2, 3) ∈ R but (3,2)∉R
∴R is not symmetric
∵(4, 2) and (2,4)∈R but (4,4)∉R
⇒R is not transitive

question: eqn_key_0
equation:
\begin{align*}
\text{Given } f(x) &= \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{2x}{1-x^2}\right) = 2 \tan^{-1}x \\
\text{for } x &\in (-1, 1) \\
\text{If } x \in (-1, 1) &\Rightarrow \tan^{-1}x \in \left(-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{\pi}{4}\right) \\
\Rightarrow 2\tan^{-1}x &\in \left(-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right) \\
\text{Clearly, range of } f(x) &= \left(-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right) \\
\text{For } f \text{ to be onto, codomain} &= \text{range} \\
\therefore \text{Co-domain of function } &= B = \left(-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)
\end{align*}

question:
Let R = {(3, 3), (6, 6), (9, 9), (12, 12), (6, 12), (3, 9),(3, 12), (3, 6)} be a
relation on the set
A = {3, 6, 9, 12}. The relation is
solution:
R is reflexive and transitive only.
Here(3, 3), (6, 6), (9, 9), (12, 12) ∈ R [So, reflexive ]
(3, 6), (6, 12), (3, 12) ∈ R[ So, transitive ]
∵(3, 6) ∈ R but (6,3)∉R[ So, non-symmetric ]
ques.subject: Maths

question:
A real valued function f (x) satisfies the functional equation
f (x − y) = f (x)f (y) − f (a − x)f (a + y) where a is a given constant and
f (0) = 0, f (2a − x) is equal to
equation:
\begin{align*}
\text{Given that } f(0) &= 0 \text{ and put } x = 0, y = 0 \\
f(0) &= f^2(0) - f^2(a) \\
\Rightarrow f^2(a) &= 0 \Rightarrow f(a) = 0 \\
f(2a-x) &= f(a - (x-a)) \\
&= f(a)f(x-a) - f(0)f(x) \\
&= f(a)f(x-a) - f(x) = -f(x) \\
\Rightarrow f(2a-x) &= -f(x)
\end{align*}
ques.subject: Maths

question:
Let W denote the words in the English dictionary. Define the relation R
by R = (x, y) ∈ W × W | the words x and y have at least one letter in
common.} Then R is
solution:
Clearly (x, x) ∈ R, ∀x ∈ W
∵ All letter are common in some word. So R is reflexive.
Let (x, y) ∈ R, then (y, x) ∈ R as x and y have at least one letter in common. So, R is symmetric.
But R is not transitive for example 
Let x = BOY , y = TOY and z = THREE then (x, y) ∈ R( O, Y are common ) and (y, z) ∈ R( T is common) but (x, z) ∉ R. (as no letter is common)
ques.subject: Maths

Y = { y ∈ N : y = 4x + 3 for some x ∈ N }.
Show that f is invertible and its inverse is
ques.subject: Maths

options: Neither S nor T is an equivalence relation on R
Both S and T are equivalence relation on R
S is an equivalence relation on R but T is not
T is an equivalence relation on R but S is not
solution:
Given that
S = { (x, y) : y = x + 1 and 0 < x < 2 }
∵x ≠ x + 1 for any x ∈ (0, 2)
⇒(x, x) ∉ S
So, S is not reflexive.
Hence, S in not an equivalence relation.
Given T = {x, y) : x − y is an integer }
∵x − x = 0 is an integer, ∀x ∈ R
So, T is reflexive.
Let (x, y) ∈ T ⇒ x − y is an integer then y − x is also an integer ⇒(y, x) ∈ R
∴T is symmetric
If x − y is an integer and y − z is an integer then (x − y) + (y − z) = x − z is also an integer.
∴T is transitive
Hence T is an equivalence relation.
ques.subject: Maths

question: eqn_key_0
equation:
\begin{align*}
\text{Given that } f(x) &= (x+1)^2 - 1, \quad x \ge -1 \\
\text{Clearly } D_f &= [-1, \infty) \text{ but co-domain is not given. Therefore } f(x) \text{ is onto.} \\
\text{Let } f(x_1) &= f(x_2) \\
\Rightarrow (x_1 + 1)^2 - 1 &= (x_2 + 1)^2 - 1 \\
\Rightarrow x_1 &= x_2 \\
\therefore f(x) &\text{ is one-one, hence } f(x) \text{ is bijection.} \\
\because (x+1) &\text{ being something +ve, } \forall x > -1 \\
\therefore f^{-1}(x) &\text{ will exist. Let } (x+1)^2 - 1 = y \\
\Rightarrow x+1 &= \sqrt{y+1} \text{ (+ve square root as } x+1 \ge 0) \\
\Rightarrow x &= -1 + \sqrt{y+1} \\
\Rightarrow f^{-1}(x) &= \sqrt{x+1} - 1 \\
\text{Then } f(x) &= f^{-1}(x) \\
\Rightarrow (x+1)^2 - 1 &= \sqrt{x+1} - 1 \\
\Rightarrow (x+1)^2 &= \sqrt{x+1} \Rightarrow (x+1)^4 = (x+1) \\
\Rightarrow (x+1)[(x+1)^3 - 1] &= 0 \Rightarrow x = -1, 0 \\

\therefore \text{ The statement- 1 and statement- 2 both are true. Statement-2 is a correct explanation for Statement-1.}
\end{align*}
options:
Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true. Statement-2 is not a correct explanation for
Statement-1.
Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is false
Statement-1 is false, Statement-2 is true
Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true. Statement-2 is a correct explanation for Statement-1
ques.subject: Maths

question: eqn_key_0
equation:
\begin{align*}
\text{Given } f \text{ is a bijective function} \\
\therefore f : [1, \infty) \rightarrow [1, \infty) \\
f(x) &= (x-1)^2 + 1, \quad x \ge 1 \\
\text{Let } y &= (x-1)^2 + 1 \Rightarrow (x-1)^2 = y-1 \\
\Rightarrow x &= 1 \pm \sqrt{y-1} \Rightarrow f^{-1}(y) = 1 \pm \sqrt{y-1} \\
\Rightarrow f^{-1}(x) &= 1 + \sqrt{x-1} \quad \{\because x \ge 1\} \\
\text{Hence statement-2 is correct} \\
\text{Now } f(x) &= f^{-1}(x) \\
\Rightarrow f(x) &= x \Rightarrow (x-1)^2 + 1 = x \\
\Rightarrow x^2 - 3x + 2 &= 0 \Rightarrow x = 1, 2 \\
\text{Hence statement-1 is correct}
\end{align*}
options: Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is a correct explanation for Statement-1

Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is NOT a correct explanation for
Statement-1
Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is false
Statement-1 is false, Statement-2 is true.
ques.subject: Maths

question:
Let R be the set of real numbers.
Statement-1: A = { (x, y) ∈ R × R : y − x is an integer } is an equivalence
relation on R.
Statement- 2: B = {(x, y) ∈ R × R: x = αy for some rational number α }
is an equivalence relation on R.
options:
Statement-1 is false, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is not a correct explanation for
Statement-1.
Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is false.
Statement-1 is false, Statement-2 is true.
Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is a correct explanation for Statement-1.
solution:
∵ x − x = 0 ∈ I (∴R is reflexive)
Let (x, y) ∈ R as x − y and y − x ∈ I ( ∵R is symmetric)
Now x − y ∈ I and y − z ∈ I ⇒ x − z ∈ I
So, R is translative.
Hence R is equivalence.
Similarly as x = αy for α = 1 . B is reflexive symmetric and translative. Hence B is equivalence.
Both relations are equivalence but not the correct explanation.
ques.subject: Maths

question: eqn_key_0
options: Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is false.
Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is a correct explanation for Statement-1.
Statement-1 is false, Statement-2 is true.

Statement-1 is false, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is not a correct explanation for
Statement-1.
solution:
Let A and B be non-empty sets in R.
Let f : A → B is bijective function.
Clearly statement - 1 is true which says that f is an onto function.
Statement -2 is also true statement but it is not the correct explanation for statement-1

question: eqn_key_0
equation:
\begin{align*}
f(x) &= \frac{x}{1+|x|}, \quad x \in \mathbb{R} \\
\text{If } x > 0, |x| &= x \Rightarrow f(x) = \frac{x}{1+x} \quad \text{which is not defined for } x = -1 \\
\text{If } x < 0, |x| &= -x \Rightarrow f(x) = \frac{x}{1-x} \quad \text{which is not defined for } x = 1 \\
\text{Thus } f(x) &\text{ defined for all values of } \mathbb{R} \text{ except } 1 \text{ and } -1 \\
\text{Hence, range } &= (-1, 1)
\end{align*}
ques.subject: Maths

question: eqn_key_0
equation:
\begin{align*}
\text{A relation on a set } A \text{ is said to be symmetric iff } (a, b) \in A \Rightarrow (b, a) \in A, \forall a, b \in A \\
\text{Here } A = \{3, 4, 6, 8, 9\} \\
\text{Number of order pairs of } A \times A = 5 \times 5 = 25 \\
\text{Divide } 25 \text{ order pairs of } A \text{ times } A \text{ in } 3 \text{ parts as follows:} \\
\text{Part - A : } (3, 3), (4, 4), (6, 6), (8, 8), (9, 9) \\
\text{Part - B : } (3, 4), (3, 6), (3, 8), (3, 9), (4, 6), (4, 8), (4, 9), (6, 8), (6, 9), (8, 9) \\
\text{Part - C : } (4, 3), (6, 3), (8, 3), (9, 3), (6, 4), (8, 4), (9, 4), (8, 6), (9, 6), (9, 8) \\
\text{In part - A, both components of each order pair are same.} \\
\text{In part - B, both components are different but not two such order pairs are present in which first component of one order pair is the second component of another order pair and vice-versa.} \\
\text{In part-C, only reverse of the order pairs of part -B are present i.e., if } (a, b) \text{ is present in part - B, then } (b, a) \text{ will be present in part -C} \\
\text{For example } (3, 4) \text{ is present in part - B and } (4, 3) \text{ present in part -C.} \\
\text{Number of order pair in A, B and C are } 5, 10 \text{ and } 10 \text{ respectively.} \\
\text{In any symmetric relation on set } A, \text{ if any order pair of part -B is present then its reverse order pair of part -C will must be also present.} \\
\text{Hence number of symmetric relation on set } A \text{ is equal to the number of all relations on a set } D, \text{ which contains all the order pairs of part -A and part- B.} \\
\text{Now } n(D) = n(A) + n(B) = 5 + 10 = 15 \\
\text{Hence number of all relations on set } D = (2)^{15} \\
\Rightarrow \text{Number of symmetric relations on set } D = (2)^{15}
\end{align*}
ques.subject: Maths

question:
If P(S) denotes the set of all subsets of a given set S, then the number of
one-to-one functions from the set S = {1, 2, 3} to the set P(S) is
equation:
\begin{align*}
\text{Let } S &= \{1, 2, 3\} \rightarrow n(S) = 3 \\
\text{Now, } P(S) &= \text{set of all subsets of } S \\
\text{total no. of subsets } &= 2^3 = 8 \\
\therefore n[P(S)] &= 8 \\
\text{Now, number of one-to-one functions from } S \rightarrow P(S) \text{ is } {^8P_3} &= \frac{8!}{5!} = 8 \times 7 \times 6 = 336
\end{align*}
ques.subject: Maths

question:
Let R = {(3, 3), (5, 5), (9, 9), (12, 12), (5, 12), (3, 9), (3, 12), (3, 5)} be a
relation on the set A = {3, 5, 9, 12}. Then, R is :
solution:
Let R = { (3, 3), (5, 5), (9, 9), (12, 12), (5, 12), (3, 9), (3, 12), (3,5) } be a relation on set
A = {3, 5, 9, 12}
Clearly, every element of A is related to itself.
Therefore, it is a reflexive.
Now, R is not symmetry because 3 is related to 5 but 5 is not related to 3.
Also R is transitive relation because it satisfies the property that if aRb and bRc then aRc.
ques.subject: Maths

question: eqn_key_0
equation:
\begin{align*}
R &= \{(x, y) : x, y \in \mathbb{N} \text{ and } x^2 - 4xy + 3y^2 = 0 \} \\
\text{Now, } x^2 - 4xy + 3y^2 &= 0 \\
\Rightarrow (x-y)(x-3y) &= 0 \\
\therefore x &= y \text{ or } x = 3y \\
\therefore R &= \{(1, 1), (3, 1), (2, 2), (6, 2), (3, 3), (9, 3), \ldots \} \\
\text{Since } (1, 1), (2, 2), (3, 3), \ldots \text{ are present in the relation, therefore } R \text{ is reflexive.} \\
\text{Since } (3, 1) \text{ is an element of } R \text{ but } (1, 3) \text{ is not the element of } R, \text{ therefore } R \text{ is not symmetric.} \\
\text{Here } (3, 1) \in R \text{ and } (1, 1) \in R \Rightarrow (3, 1) \in R, \quad (6, 2) \in R \text{ and } (2, 2) \in R \Rightarrow (6, 2) \in R \\
\text{For all such } (a, b) \in R \text{ and } (b, c) \in R \\
\Rightarrow (a, c) \in R \\
\text{Hence } R \text{ is transitive.}
\end{align*}
options: reflexive but neither symmetric nor transitive.
ques.subject: Maths

question: eqn_key_0
equation:
\begin{align*}
\text{Since } f(x) \text{ and } g(x) \text{ are inverse of each other} \\
\therefore g'(f(x)) &= \frac{1}{f'(x)} \\
\\
\Rightarrow g'(f(x)) &= 1 + x^5 \quad \left(\because f'(x) = \frac{1}{1+x^5}\right) \\
\text{Here } x &= g(y) \\
\therefore g'(y) &= 1 + [g(y)]^5 \\
\Rightarrow g'(x) &= 1 + [g(x)]^5
\end{align*}
